Scenario: Management of confirmed chronic pancreatitis

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with confirmed chronic pancreatitis in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
A person with confirmed chronic pancreatitis should be managed by a specialist team in secondary care, but primary care may have a role in the following:

  • Providing general lifestyle advice and support
    • In particular, recommend complete abstinence from alcohol and smoking.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Alcohol - problem drinking and Smoking cessation.
  • Provision of adequate pain relief
    • Prescribe simple analgesia for mild-to-moderate pain associated with chronic pancreatitis.
      • Prescribe paracetamol or a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), for example ibuprofen, first-line.
      • Consider the addition of a weak opioid, such as codeine phosphate, if first-line analgesia alone is inadequate.
      • For more prescribing information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
    • If the person has uncontrolled pain, refer the person to secondary care (gastroenterology, pancreatico-biliary surgery, a specialist pancreatic centre, or pain clinic) for a multidisciplinary assessment. Treatment options for pain relief in secondary care includes:
      • Endoscopic therapy to remove obstructing pancreatic stones or to dilate strictures.
      • Surgery or other interventions (for example endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography [ERCP] and stenting) to relieve pain from large-duct (obstructive) chronic alcohol-related pancreatitis, or to deal with complications, such as pancreatic pseudocyst or gastric outlet obstruction.
      • Adjuvant drugs such as amitriptyline, gabapentin, or pregabalin.
      • Coeliac axis block, splanchnicectomy, or surgery if the person has poorly controlled pain from small-duct (non-obstructive) chronic alcohol-related pancreatitis.
  • Screening for diabetes mellitus
    • Offer annual screening for diabetes mellitus by checking glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c). For further information see the CKS topic on Diabetes - type 1.
  • Screening for osteoporosis 
    • Offer annual screening with a dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan for people with malabsorption or at high-risk for osteoporosis (for example previous history of low-trauma fracture). For further information, see the CKS topic on Osteoporosis - prevention of fragility fractures.
  • Referral or admission to secondary care:
    • Refer urgently (on the 2 week wait cancer pathway) to gastroenterology or a pancreatic specialist if the person has unexplained progressive weight loss. For further information, see the CKS topic on Gastrointestinal tract (upper) cancers - recognition and referral.
    • Consider urgent admission if the person presents with an episode of acute pancreatitis. For further information, see the CKS topic on Pancreatitis - acute.
    • Consider urgent referral, depending on clinical judgement, if the person presents with a complication of pancreatitis.
    • Refer specifically to:
      • A dietitian — for dietary changes, including a low-fat, high-protein, high-calorie diet with fat-soluble vitamin supplementation.
      • A diabetologist — for the management of diabetes secondary to chronic pancreatitis. 
      • Gastroenterology, pancreatico-biliary surgery, or a pancreatic centre if the person has recurrent attacks of acute pancreatitis.
  • Supporting shared-care agreements
    • Treatment that is likely to be initiated in secondary care and continued in primary care includes:
      • Pancreatic enzyme supplementation for steatorrhoea or poor nutritional status, or as a therapeutic trial for pain relief.
      • Corticosteroids for the treatment of autoimmune chronic pancreatitis.
      • Treatment of hypertriglyceridaemia or hypercalcaemia.
      • Treatment of diabetes mellitus secondary to chronic pancreatitis.
  • Providing sources of information and support
    • For example, Core (available at www.corecharity.org.uk) provides evidence-based information for people with diseases of the gut, liver, and/or pancreas.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
General lifestyle advice and support
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in two review articles [Olesen et al, 2013; BMJ, 2015].
Providing analgesia
  • These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Alcohol-use disorders: Diagnosis and clinical management of alcohol-related physical complications [NICE, 2010], a systematic review [D'Haese et al, 2014], and expert opinion in two review articles [Olesen et al, 2013; BMJ, 2015]. 
Screening for diabetes mellitus
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a clinical practice guideline on the management of chronic pancreatitis [Mayerle et al, 2013] and two review articles [Ewald and Hardt, 2013; Rickels et al, 2013]. 
Screening for osteoporosis
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article [BMJ, 2015].
Arranging referral or admission to secondary care 
  • These recommendations are based on the NICE guideline Alcohol-use disorders: Diagnosis and clinical management of alcohol-related physical complications [NICE, 2010], and expert opinion of previous reviewers of this CKS topic, and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Shared-care agreements
  • The information on shared care agreements is taken from the NICE guideline Alcohol-use disorders: Diagnosis and clinical management of alcohol-related physical complications [NICE, 2010], a clinical practice guideline Chronic pancreatitis - definition, etiology, investigation and treatment [Mayerle et al, 2013], and expert opinion in two review articles [Ketwaroo and Sheth, 2013; BMJ, 2015].
